subject: Re: [junit] Is it the best method to unit-test for Divide class...PLS Help
msgSnippet: Sandeep, That strikes me as an unexpected definition of divide (the y == 2 check seems to have no effect).  What is the context? David Saff
messageBody:
Sandeep,

That strikes me as an unexpected definition of divide (the y == 2
check seems to have no effect). What is the context?

David Saff

On Mon, Mar 14, 2011 at 5:54 AM, Sandeep <sandyridgeracer@...> wrote:
> Divide Class
>
>
> package example.div;
> public class Divide {
>        public int divide1(int x, int y) throws ArithmeticException{
>                        if (y == 2)
>                                return x / y;
>                        else
>                                return x / y;
>        }
> }
>
>
> DivideTest Class
>
> package example.div;
>
> import static org.junit.Assert.*;
>
> import org.junit.Before;
> import org.junit.Test;
>
> public class DivideTest {
>        Divide d = null;
>        @Before
>        public void setUp() {
>                d = new Divide();
>        }
>        @Test
>        public void testDivide() {
>                assertEquals(50, d.divide1(100, 2));
>                assertEquals("Result",100,d.divide1(100,1));
>        }
>        @Test(expected=ArithmeticException.class)
>        public void testDivide1(){
>                d.divide1(100, 0);
>        }
> }
>
>
>
